CONSULTATION REPORT
NAME : <NAME>
MR#: <ID> DOB: <ID><LOCATION><NAME><ID><ID>ACCT#: <ID><ID>REASON FOR CONSULTATION:
1.Large right forearm abscess secondary to IV drug abuse.2. Uncontrolled DM.HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mr. <NAME> is a <AGE> Caucasian
male, who came in with complaints of pain and swelling of the right
upper extremity, worse in the right upper forearm, which noted after
we injected intravenous heroin injection 3 days back.<NAME><AGE>Since then, he
noted pain as well as swelling, erythema.He had episodes of fever,
chills, but denies similar problems at the time of admission.He has
known history of diabetes mellitus, schizoaffective disorder.He had
prior history of multiple abscesses in the past secondary to IV drug
abuse.REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: CONSTITUTIONAL: History of fever, chills, and
rigors.Denies any recent change in vision or hearing.EAR, NOSE,MOUTH, and THROAT: Denies sore throat, rhinorrhea, post nasal drip.RESPIRATORY: Denies cough, expectoration, or sputum.No shortness of
breath.CARDIOVASCULAR: Denies chest pain, palpitations, dyspnea.GASTROINTESTINAL: Denies nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or recent
change in bowel habits, bladder habits.GENITOURINARY: Negative.ENDOCRINE: Known diabetic on insulin, but poorly controlled.HEMATOLOGIC: No compromise secondary to IV drug abuse as well as
uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.NEUROLOGIC: He is alert, oriented,
follows commands appropriately, seems to understand the gravity of the
situation.Request ID: <ID><ID>MRN:    <ID><ID>Admit:  <DATE>:    <NAME><DATE><NAME>Account #:  <ID> TYPE:          Consultation Note<ID>SERVICE DATE/TIME:      <DATE> 05:32 EDT<DATE>RESULT STATUS:          Auth (Verified)PERFORMED INFORMATION:

<LOCATION><LOCATION>Patient:<NAME><NAME>Account #: <ID><ID>Disch: <DATE><DATE>Consultation NotesALLERGIES: NO KNOWN MEDICAL ALLERGIES.MEDICATIONS: He is started on vancomycin as well as Zosyn along withIV fluids and insulin for his control of diabetes mellitus.Part of
his management is done by primary team.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Diabetes.2. Schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder.3. Hypertension.4. Hyperlipidemia.FAMILY HISTORY: Denies any significant family history.SOCIAL HISTORY: History of IV drug abuse.Denies alcohol or
smoking.PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: GENERAL: The patient is alert and oriented,
appears to be in mild to moderate distress secondary to his right
forearm swelling as well as pain.VITAL SIGNS: His pulse rate is 88,
blood pressure 148/73, respirations 18 per minute, temperature 98.3,
oxygen saturation 97% on room air, and measured weight was 70.HEENT:
Eyes; pupils are equal and reactive to light.Head, normocephalic and
atraumatic.NECK: Supple.RESPIRATORY: Lungs clear to
auscultation.GASTROINTESTINAL: Soft, nontender, and nondistended.No organomegaly.MUSCULOSKELETAL: The right upper extremity is
swollen compared to the left, swelling is more so prominent in the
forearm, mostly in the upper forearm.At the bulk of the muscle area
with area of induration, but there was no crepitus noted.On
questioning, he denies any sensory or motor deficit.On my
examination, I did not see any motor or sensory deficits as well.He
has good capillary refill and palpable radial pulse noted, which is
similar to the upper extremity.NEUROLOGIC: Alert and oriented x3.LABORATORY DATA: His laboratory data showed WBC of 14.9, hemoglobin12.9, hematocrit 39.4, platelets 224, neutrophils 84%.Sodium 119,
potassium 4.8, chloride 87, CO2 of 21, calcium 8.6, glucose 701, BUN
35, creatinine 1.24, total bilirubin 0.4, total protein 7, albumin2.2, ALT 32, AST 30, alkaline phosphatase 124.ASSESSMENT :
1. LARGE ABSCESS IN THE RIGHT FOREARM SECONDARY TO INTRAVENOUS DRUG
ABUSE AND RECENT IV DRUG INJECTION AT THAT SITE WITH SURROUNDING
ERYTHEMA AND CELLULITIS.2. UNCONTROLLED DIABETES MELLITUS WITH BLOOD SUGARS OVER 700.
3. HYPONATREMIA, MAY BE SECONDARY TO HIGH BLOOD SUGARS.PLAN: In view of above findings, we offered him incision and
drainage, possible debridement of the right forearm abscess.The
patient does not want to be done this evening and he wants to wait
till next day morning.Risks, benefits, and possible complications,Request ID: <ID><ID>MRN:    <ID><ID>Admit:  <DATE><DATE>

<LOCATION><LOCATION>Patient:<NAME><NAME>Account #: <ID><ID>Disch: <DATE><DATE>Consultation Notes
which include death, worsening of his general condition, as well as
spreading cellulitis with possible compartment syndrome, risk of
losing the extremity were explained, but the patient does seems to
understand the risks, but do not want surgery to be performed tonight.We would agree with medicine recommendation of controlling blood
sugars in the meantime and optimize his overall condition.We would
advise to continue broad spectrum antibiotics.Thank you very much for this interesting consult.The patient is
consented for surgery at this time.Electronically Signed by

REASON FOR CONSULTATION: Right forearm abscess.HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a <AGE> active intravenous drug user,
injected heroin 4 days ago and came to the ER with massive swelling of his right forearm.<AGE>He
was seen by Surgery.Notes indicate that he did not want to go to the OR yesterday.He is
supposed to go for an OR today.As per the nursing staff, this abscess spontaneously burst
draining greenish purulence.It has been dressed up currently to keep that in check.He is
going to the OR tonight.He was started on intravenous Zosyn and vancomycin.InfectiousDisease consultation was requested for further evaluation and comanagement.The
ultrasound indicates that the abscess is at least 7.9 X 6.3 X 6.1 cm.The patient is afebrile at
this time, hemodynamically stable, and his WBC count was 14.9 on admission with 84%
neutrophils.Blood cultures are in the lab.Wound cultures have not been done.Blood
glucose levels were 700 on admission, 214 today.Infectious Disease consultation is being
requested for further evaluation and comanagement.PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Diabetes.2. Hypertension.3. Hyperlipidemia.4. Schizoaffective disorder.5. Intravenous drug user.PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: He had multiple abscesses drained in the past.ALLERGIES: NONE.PERSONAL AND SOCIAL HISTORY: As mentioned above.He has a history of drug use and
he was also injecting 4 days ago.He denies alcohol use and smoking.NAME: <NAME>
MRN: <ID><NAME><ID>ACCT: <ID><ID>ADM: <DATE><DATE><LOCATION>: <DATE><LOCATION><DATE>DOB: <DATE><DATE>ROOM:
<LOCATION> REPORT<LOCATION>Page 1CONSULTANT:    <NAME>, MD
REQUESTED BY:  <NAME>, MD
CONSULT DATE:  <DATE><NAME><NAME><DATE>

FAMILY HISTORY: Not contributory at this time.O<NAME>IENT MEDICATIONS: He is supposed to be on aspart insulin, glargine insulin,
lovastatin, fluphenazine, amantadine, multivitamin with minerals, quetiapine, omega-3
polyunsaturated fatty acids, pioglitazone, enalapril, and glipizide.REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: He had low-grade fevers.No chills.No respiratory issues.No
precordial chest pain.No nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain.No dysuria or
hematuria.The right forearm had a massive swelling.It has started to drain spontaneously.He does not complain of any numbness of the fingers though.He does have some
extrapyramidal movements of the mouth, which is his baseline.Otherwise, no focal deficits
reported.A review of 10-point systems has been done.They are pertinent for the above,
negative for the rest.
MEDICATIONS: Normal saline at 100 mL/hour, vancomycin 1 g q. 12 hourly, Zosyn 3.375 g
q.6 hourly, aspart insulin, Protonix, quetiapine, Tylenol, atorvastatin, glargine insulin, sliding
scale insulin, and morphine.PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: GENERAL: This is a moderately built, relatively cachectic male,
but documented to have a weight of 72 kgs.He looks very thin and emaciated.VITAL
SIGNS: Are as follows, T-max and T-current of 99.9 and 98.2, pulse rate is 72, respiratory
rate 18, blood pressure 149/37, and O2 saturation 100% on room air.HEENT: Reactive
pupils.Positive pallor.He is edentulous.He has buccolingual dyskinesia.NECK: Supple.No signs of meningismus.LUNGS: Clear.CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM: No audible
murmurs.ABDOMEN: Scaphoid, benign, nontender.Bowel sounds heard.RECTAL:
Deferred.GU SYSTEM: Exam deferred.MUSCULOSKELETAL SYSTEM: No joint
swellings or tenderness.EXTREMITIES: The right forearm has a large abscess with
surrounding cellulitis.It is draining pus.Radial pulses are felt well.The hand is warm to
touch.CNS: He is alert, awake, and oriented to all modalities.LABORATORY DATA: Significant labs; BUN and creatinine of 26 and 1.09.On admission,
glucose was 701 and today it is 214.Sodium was very low 119 on admission, gone up to 131
today.Beta hydroxybutyrate 9.5 on admission.Urinalysis unremarkable.WBC count 14.9,
hemoglobin and hematocrit of 12.9 and 39.4, platelet count 234, neutrophils 84%.Two sets of

<LOCATION> REPORT<LOCATION>Page 2

blood cultures are in the lab.Ultrasound of the upper extremity showed a large abscess.Chest x-ray, no infiltrates.ASSESSMENT:
1.LEUKOCYTOSIS SECONDARY TO INFECTION.2. RIGHT FOREARM ABSCESS SECONDARY TO INTRAVENOUS DRUG USER WITHHEROIN.3. ACTIVE INTRAVENOUS DRUG USER.4. UNCONTROLLED DIABETES.5.
SEVERE HYPONATREMIA ON ADMISSION, LIKELY SECONDARY TO
HYPERGLYCEMIA, IMPROVING NOW.6. SCHIZOAFFECTIVE DISORDER.7. HYPERTENSION AND HYPERLIPIDEMIA.SUGGESTIONS:
1. I agree with broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage.2. Continue IV vancomycin 1 g q. 12 hourly.3. Continue IV Zosyn 3.375 g q.6 hourly.4. Probiotics.5. Incision and drainage today and obtain OR cultures.6.
We will follow up the clinical course, pending culture, and streamline antibiotics if
indicated.7. Overall prognosis guarded.8. Care of plan was discussed with the patient and nursing staff.Electronically Signed by<NAME>, MD <DATE> 02:03 P<NAME><DATE><NAME>, MD

as well as uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.NEUROLOGIC: He is alert, oriented, follows
commands appropriately, seems to understand the gravity of the situation.ALLERGIES: NO KNOWN MEDICAL ALLERGIES.MEDICATIONS: He is started on vancomycin as well as Zosyn along with IV fluids and insulin
for his control of diabetes mellitus.Part of his management is done by primary team.

Schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder.3. Hypertension.4. Hyperlipidemia.FAMILY HISTORY: Denies any significant family history.SOCIAL HISTORY: History of IV drug abuse.Denies alcohol or smoking.PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: GENERAL: The patient is alert and oriented, appears to be in
mild to moderate distress secondary to his right forearm swelling as well as pain.VITAL
SIGNS: His pulse rate is 88, blood pressure 148/73, respirations 18 per minute, temperature98.3, oxygen saturation 97% on room air, and measured weight was 70.HEENT: Eyes;
pupils are equal and reactive to light.Head, normocephalic and atraumatic.NECK: Supple.RESPIRATORY: Lungs clear to auscultation.GASTROINTESTINAL: Soft, nontender, and
nondistended.No organomegaly.MUSCULOSKELETAL: The right upper extremity is
swollen compared to the left, swelling is more so prominent in the forearm, mostly in the upper
forearm.At the bulk of the muscle area with area of induration, but there was no crepitus
noted.On questioning, he denies any sensory or motor deficit.On my examination, I did not
see any motor or sensory deficits as well.He has good capillary refill and palpable radial
pulse noted, which is similar to the upper extremity.NEUROLOGIC: Alert and oriented x3.LABORATORY DATA: His laboratory data showed WBC of 14.9, hemoglobin 12.9,
hematocrit 39.4, platelets 224, neutrophils 84%.Sodium 119, potassium 4.8, chloride 87,
CO2 of 21, calcium 8.6, glucose 701, BUN 35, creatinine 1.24, total bilirubin 0.4, total protein
7, albumin 2.2, ALT 32, AST 30, alkaline phosphatase 124.ASSESSMENT:
1.LARGE ABSCESS IN THE RIGHT FOREARM SECONDARY TO INTRAVENOUS DRUG
ABUSE AND RECENT IV DRUG INJECTION AT THAT SITE WITH SURROUNDING
ERYTHEMA AND CELLULITIS.2.
UNCONTROLLED DIABETES MELLITUS WITH BLOOD SUGARS OVER 700.
3.
HYPONATREMIA, MAY BE SECONDARY TO HIGH BLOOD SUGARS.PLAN: In view of above findings, we offered him incision and drainage, possible debridement
of the right forearm abscess.The patient does not want to be done this evening and he wants
to wait till next day morning.Risks, benefits, and possible complications, which include death,NAME: <NAME>

(<LOCATION>) <LOCATION> IR <LOCATION><LOCATION><LOCATION><LOCATION>Indication: IV access.Medications: 1% lidocaine, subcutaneous.Fluoroscopy time: 3 seconds.Technique:A fter informed and written consent was obtained, the patient was placed supine on the fluoroscopy table.The left arm was sterilely
prepped and draped.1% lidocaine was injected into the subcutaneous tissues of the medial arm.Basilic vein was identified with
ultrasound.Vein was patent.A micropuncture needle was advanced into the vein under ultrasound guidance.Ultrasound images
were obtained and recorded.An 018 wire was advanced into the needle and the needle was removed.A 5 French peel-away sheath
was then advanced over the wire.Subsequently, a 5 French dual lumen power PICC was placed with catheter tip in junction of
superior vena cava and right atrium.The length of the PICC is 37 cm.Sterile dressing was applied.Patient tolerated procedure well without any immediate complication.Permanent fluoroscopic image was
recordedIMPRESSION:
Successful ultrasound and fluoroscopic guided power PICC placement with tip at the level of the superior vena cava/right atrium.Electronically Signed By: <NAME>

Real-time sonographic evaluation was performed of the deep venous system of the right upper extremity from the jugular vein to the
antecubital segment.Static grayscale, color and duplex Doppler images are submitted.The examination of the venous system of the right upper extremity is negative for filling defect.There is normal grayscale
compression, color flow and duplex Doppler signal throughout the visualized venous structures.Just distal to the antecubital fossa is a large complexin echotexture subcutaneous collection measuring 7.9x6.3x6.1 cm.Interrogation
with color Doppler does not demonstrate significant centralize blood flow.Impression:1.Negative for evidence of deep vein thrombos is right upper extremity.2. Indeterminate 7.9 X 6.3 x6x1 cm subcutaneous mass/collection.It appears relatively avascular.Differential considerations include
hematoma and abscess.Correlation with clinical history is recommended.If clinically warranted, this would be easily accessible for
needle aspiration.Electronically Signed By: <NAME>

DATE OF SURGERY: <DATE><DATE>PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Abscess in the right forearm secondary to intravenous drug abuse.POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Abscess in the right forearm secondary to intravenous drug
abuse and necrosis of soft tissue..SURGEON: <NAME>, MD
PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
1.<NAME>Incision and drainage of the right forearm abscess.2. Debridement of necrotic soft tissueFINDINGS: Mr. <NAME> is a <AGE> Caucasian male, who injected heroin 3 weeks prior to
presentation and presented with swelling of the right forearm over the anterior muscular
compartment close to the elbow joint abscess.<NAME><AGE>He initially refused to proceed with surgery and he
also is a known diabetic, presented with blood sugars over 500.Over the course of next day, his
blood sugars are corrected to relatively normal baseline and he was started on intravenous
antibiotics.Next day, he started draining and it was not drained completely, so he was brought into
the operating room for incision and drainage and evacuation of the pus.PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: The patient was brought into the operating room.Preoperative time-out
was performed.Antibiotic dose of vancomycin and Zosyn was given prior to the surgery.Prior to
the surgery, incision was made over the most fluctuant part of the abscess and it was deepened
further.About an inch area of the skin was necrotic and that was the area it was partially draining
pus.That part of the necrotic skin was excised and a small counter incision was given to facilitate
this drainage of the abscess.Subsequently, generous wound irrigation was given to Pulsavac
lavage and hemostasis found to be secure.Subsequently large abscess cavity was packed with
iodine soaked Kerlix gauze and hemostasis further confirmed to be secure.Blood loss was
approximately 50 mL.Sponge count, lap count, and instrument count was correct.Wound class is
infected.The patient subsequently transferred to PACU in stable condition.NAME: <NAME>
